HERB_001.title: Spearmint
HERB_001.summary: The foundation of Moroccan mint tea and one of the most ubiquitous herbs in daily life. Fresh bundles are kept in homes year-round, used for tea preparation, cooking, and as a symbol of hospitality.

Identification: Bright green pointed leaves with serrated edges
Square stem typical of mint family
Distinct cool, sweet aroma when crushed
Grows in bushy clumps when cultivated
How_it_shows_up_in_Morocco: Sold in large fresh bundles at every souk and grocery
Grown in home gardens and on farms throughout the country
Added to the iconic atay (mint tea) preparation
Used fresh in salads and cooked dishes
Traditional_uses: Household infusion for digestive comfort after meals
Added to tea for daily enjoyment
Notes_on_variation: Moroccan spearmint considered particularly aromatic
Several local varieties exist with subtle differences
Cautions: Concentrated preparations may cause discomfort in sensitive individuals

HERB_002.title: Thyme
HERB_002.summary: A cornerstone of Moroccan herbal practice, gathered wild from mountain slopes. Prepared as winter infusions and used in fumigation. Central to household wellness routines in colder months.

Identification: Small woody shrub with tiny grey-green leaves
Highly aromatic when crushed or dried
Pink or white flowers in summer
Grows wild on rocky, dry slopes
How_it_shows_up_in_Morocco: Gathered wild from Atlas and Rif mountains
Sold dried in bundles at herbal shops (attarine)
Used in cooking for tagines and marinades
Traditional_uses: Winter infusion for respiratory and digestive comfort
Added to bread and grilled meats
Notes_on_variation: Wild Moroccan thyme more pungent than cultivated European varieties
Several Thymus species grow in Morocco
Cautions: May irritate sensitive skin in concentrated form

HERB_003.title: Rosemary
HERB_003.summary: Abundant wild shrub found across Moroccan mountains. Used in cooking, as a hair rinse, and for its invigorating scent. The Arabic name 'Azir' means 'that which gives strength.'

Identification: Woody evergreen shrub with needle-like leaves
Can grow quite large in wild conditions
How_it_shows_up_in_Morocco: Wild on mountain hillsides throughout the country
Sold fresh and dried in souks
Traditional_uses: Hair rinse for strengthening and shine
Notes_on_variation: Wild Moroccan rosemary highly aromatic
Quality varies by region and altitude
Cautions: Not for those with seizure disorders in concentrated form

HERB_004.title: Sage
HERB_004.summary: Aromatic herb used primarily for oral care and as a general household infusion. Less prominent than thyme but valued for its strong character and traditional applications.

How_it_shows_up_in_Morocco: Found wild on dry rocky slopes in mountain regions
Less common than thyme but readily available
Traditional_uses: Infusion used as a mouth rinse for oral care
Notes_on_variation: Several Salvia species exist in Morocco
Wild varieties may differ from cultivated

HERB_005.title: Oregano
HERB_005.summary: Often sold interchangeably with thyme under the name 'zaatar.' Used for digestive comfort and as a warming culinary herb, particularly in northern Morocco.

Identification: Small rounded leaves on branching stems
How_it_shows_up_in_Morocco: Wild in Rif and northern mountains
Often mixed with or sold as zaatar
Used in meat dishes and grilled foods
Notes_on_variation: Often confused with or sold alongside thyme
Zaatar name used for both herbs regionally

HERB_006.title: Chamomile
HERB_006.summary: One of the most popular household infusions in Morocco. Given to children and adults alike for calming and digestive ease. The dried flowers are a staple in every herbal shop.

Identification: Small daisy-like flowers with white petals and yellow centers
How_it_shows_up_in_Morocco: Grows wild in plains and fields
Sold dried in every herbal shop and pharmacy
One of the most common household infusions
Notes_on_variation: German chamomile most common
Roman chamomile also exists but less common
Cautions: Rare allergies in those sensitive to Asteraceae family

HERB_007.title: Wormwood (Shiba)
HERB_007.summary: An intensely bitter herb used only in very small quantities. Known for its strong digestive bitters and vermifuge properties. Requires knowledgeable use due to toxicity concerns.

Identification: Intensely bitter taste and pungent aroma
How_it_shows_up_in_Morocco: Sold dried in small quantities at herbal shops
Known as a powerful bitter preparation
Traditional_uses: Very small amounts as digestive bitter
Notes_on_variation: Different from Artemisia herba-alba (chih) though related
This species (absinthium) is more potent
Cautions: TOXIC in large doses - use minimal quantities only
Contains thujone which can cause seizures

HERB_008.title: Rue
HERB_008.summary: A powerful plant used almost exclusively for ritual purposes and protective fumigation. Rarely ingested due to toxicity. Handle with care as it causes skin photosensitivity.

How_it_shows_up_in_Morocco: Grown in gardens and found in markets
Used primarily for fumigation and ritual
Notes_on_variation: Used for ritual rather than therapeutic purposes
Cautions: TOXIC if ingested in any significant quantity
Handle with gloves or wash hands thoroughly

HERB_009.title: Fennel
HERB_009.summary: Versatile herb with sweet anise-flavored seeds used extensively for digestive comfort. Associated with nursing mothers. The bulb, leaves, and seeds all have culinary applications.

How_it_shows_up_in_Morocco: Seeds sold in every spice shop
Traditional_uses: Given to nursing mothers (associated with milk production)
Notes_on_variation: Bronze fennel exists but green more common
Seeds vary in size and intensity
Cautions: Avoid concentrated preparations during pregnancy due to estrogenic compounds

HERB_010.title: Anise
HERB_010.summary: Sweet licorice-flavored seeds used for digestive comfort and baking. A staple in Moroccan pantries, often given in weak infusions to soothe children.

How_it_shows_up_in_Morocco: Sold in spice shops throughout the country
Traditional_uses: Very weak infusions traditionally given to fussy infants
Notes_on_variation: Not the same as star anise (different plant entirely)
May be confused with fennel seeds

HERB_011.title: Cumin
HERB_011.summary: Foundational Moroccan spice with warm earthy flavor. Used in virtually every savory dish. Seed infusion traditionally prepared for digestive comfort.

How_it_shows_up_in_Morocco: Present in tagines, kefta, soups, harira
Notes_on_variation: Easily confused with caraway by non-locals
Quality varies significantly
Cautions: Large amounts may be irritating to some

HERB_012.title: Coriander
HERB_012.summary: Dual-purpose herb with fresh leaves and dried seeds used differently. Fresh coriander is essential in Moroccan cooking. Seeds have a completely different, warmer flavor.

Identification: Fresh: Flat, parsley-like leaves with distinct citrus aroma
Seeds: Small round tan seeds with warm nutty flavor
Annual plant that bolts to seed in heat
How_it_shows_up_in_Morocco: Fresh bundles at every vegetable market
One of the most used fresh herbs
Traditional_uses: Seeds traditionally used for digestive comfort
Preparation_forms: Fresh leaves in salads, chermoula, tagines
Notes_on_variation: Leaf taste is genetically divisive - some find it soapy
Seeds taste completely different from leaves
Cautions: Some have genetic aversion to leaf taste

HERB_013.title: Caraway
HERB_013.summary: Warm spice used in breads and as a digestive preparation. Particularly associated with postpartum recovery in traditional practice.

Traditional_uses: Digestive comfort especially after heavy meals
Notes_on_variation: Easily confused with cumin by appearance
Tastes quite different

HERB_014.title: Fenugreek
HERB_014.summary: Important traditional herb especially for new mothers. Seeds have a distinctive maple-like aroma when cooked. Associated with appetite and strength in recovery.

Traditional_uses: Given to new mothers for recovery
Notes_on_variation: Strong distinctive smell that permeates
Causes body odor with heavy use
Cautions: Causes distinctive body odor with regular use

HERB_015.title: Nigella (Black Seed)
HERB_015.summary: Highly regarded traditional seed known as habba sawda or sanouj. Considered one of the most valued preparations. Used both culinarily and in traditional wellness practice.

How_it_shows_up_in_Morocco: Sold in all spice and herbal shops
Traditional_uses: Considered highly beneficial in traditional practice
Part of cultural and religious tradition
Notes_on_variation: Sometimes adulterated with other black seeds
Quality varies
Cautions: Avoid very large doses during pregnancy

HERB_016.title: Ginger
HERB_016.summary: Warming spice used extensively in Moroccan cooking and traditional preparations. Essential in cold weather. Both fresh and dried forms are common.

Identification: Fresh vs dried have different intensity
Notes_on_variation: Fresh and dried behave differently in cooking
Quality varies significantly

HERB_017.title: Turmeric
HERB_017.summary: Golden spice used primarily for coloring and as part of spice blends. Less central to Moroccan cuisine than South Asian but present in ras el hanout and some preparations.

How_it_shows_up_in_Morocco: Part of ras el hanout blend
Notes_on_variation: Sometimes adulterated with cheaper colorants
Quality varies
Cautions: Avoid therapeutic doses with gallbladder issues

HERB_018.title: Cinnamon
HERB_018.summary: Essential Moroccan spice used in both sweet and savory dishes. Fundamental to pastries, tagines, and beverages. Associated with warmth and hospitality.

Identification: Rolled bark sticks or ground powder
How_it_shows_up_in_Morocco: Sold in sticks and powder everywhere
Notes_on_variation: Cassia vs Ceylon often mixed or mislabeled
Cassia more common and pungent
Cautions: Cassia contains coumarin - avoid large daily doses long-term

HERB_019.title: Lavender
HERB_019.summary: Abundant wild plant in Moroccan mountains. Dried flowers used for their calming scent. Important for the local distillation industry producing hydrosol (maazhar).

How_it_shows_up_in_Morocco: Wild in Atlas and Rif mountains
Notes_on_variation: Several species grow in Morocco
Wild varieties particularly aromatic

HERB_020.title: Lemon Verbena (Louiza)
HERB_020.summary: One of the most beloved Moroccan tisane herbs. The intensely lemony leaves make a calming evening infusion. Grown in gardens throughout the country.

Notes_on_variation: Not the same as regular verbena (Verbena officinalis)
South American origin but thoroughly adopted
Cautions: One of the most popular household herbs

HERB_021.title: Pennyroyal
HERB_021.summary: Popular winter infusion herb with a strong minty character. Common in mountain regions. Requires moderation due to toxicity concerns in large amounts.

Identification: Small oval leaves on creeping stems
How_it_shows_up_in_Morocco: Wild in mountain regions near streams
Notes_on_variation: Distinct from spearmint though related
Much stronger character
Cautions: TOXIC in large amounts or as essential oil

HERB_022.title: Marjoram
HERB_022.summary: Gentle herb related to oregano but sweeter and milder. Used for calming infusions and in some cooking. Common in northern Morocco.

How_it_shows_up_in_Morocco: Wild in Rif and northern mountains
Less common than oregano but available
Notes_on_variation: Often confused with oregano
Milder and sweeter

HERB_023.title: Henna
HERB_023.summary: Central to Moroccan material culture for hair and skin decoration. Pure henna is generally safe; black henna is dangerous. Associated with celebrations and weekly care routines.

How_it_shows_up_in_Morocco: Weekly hair treatment for many women
Traditional_uses: Associated with cooling properties in hot climates
Preparation_forms: Powder mixed with liquid to paste
Notes_on_variation: Quality varies by region
Pure henna vs adulterated products
Cautions: NEVER use 'black henna' - contains PPD causing severe reactions

HERB_024.title: Myrtle
HERB_024.summary: Aromatic shrub common in northern coastal Morocco. Leaf infusion used for respiratory comfort. Hydrosol distilled and used in households.

How_it_shows_up_in_Morocco: Wild in Rif and northern coastal scrubland
Notes_on_variation: Arabic name rihan sometimes confused with basil

HERB_025.title: Eucalyptus
HERB_025.summary: Introduced tree now common throughout Morocco. Leaves used for respiratory comfort especially in winter. Steam inhalation is a widespread household practice.

Notes_on_variation: Several species exist
Cautions: Not for internal use in large amounts
Keep oil away from face of infants and young children

HERB_026.title: Argan
HERB_026.summary: Iconic Moroccan endemic tree. Two types of oil: culinary (roasted) and cosmetic (raw). Central to Souss culture and increasingly important economically.

Identification: Thorny tree endemic to southwest Morocco
Small oval fruits with hard nuts
How_it_shows_up_in_Morocco: Culinary oil for amlou and dipping
Cosmetic oil for hair and skin
Traditional_uses: Cosmetic oil for skin and hair
Notes_on_variation: Cosmetic and culinary oils are different preparations
Adulteration is common
Cautions: Don't use culinary oil for cosmetic purposes

HERB_027.title: Prickly Pear
HERB_027.summary: Ubiquitous naturalized cactus. Fruit eaten fresh in summer. Seed oil is a valued cosmetic. Handle carefully due to tiny spines (glochids).

Identification: Covered in spines and tiny glochids
How_it_shows_up_in_Morocco: Fruit sold on streets in summer
Notes_on_variation: Many color varieties of fruit
Cautions: Handle carefully - tiny glochids cause irritation
Fruit mildly laxative if eaten in excess

HERB_028.title: Saffron
HERB_028.summary: Precious spice from Taliouine region. Harvested in November. Used for coloring, flavoring, and considered warming and strengthening. Often adulterated.

How_it_shows_up_in_Morocco: Used in special dishes and teas
Preparation_forms: Added to rice, tagines, desserts, tea
Notes_on_variation: Often adulterated with safflower, turmeric, or dyed threads
Authentic saffron is expensive

HERB_029.title: Orange Blossom
HERB_029.summary: The distilled hydrosol (maazhar) is essential to Moroccan hospitality and cuisine. Intensely floral, used in pastries, beverages, and offered in water to guests.

How_it_shows_up_in_Morocco: Bitter orange trees in Fes, Marrakech, Gharb
Notes_on_variation: Ensure food-grade hydrosol not perfume quality

HERB_030.title: Rose
HERB_030.summary: The Dades Valley 'Valley of Roses' produces Morocco's famous rose products. Hydrosol used for face care and hospitality. Petals at celebrations.

How_it_shows_up_in_Morocco: Hydrosol and dried petals sold widely
Notes_on_variation: Quality varies widely
Synthetic additives common in cheap products

HERB_031.title: Geranium
HERB_031.summary: Rose-scented garden plant kept for its aromatic leaves. Rubbed between hands for pleasant scent. Common in urban gardens and on balconies.

Traditional_uses: Aromatic use - leaves rubbed for scent
Notes_on_variation: Scented geranium vs common geranium are different
Cautions: Generally safe for topical and aromatic use

HERB_032.title: Clove
HERB_032.summary: Intensely warming spice used in desserts and savory dishes. Chewed traditionally for oral freshness and discomfort. Part of winter preparations.

How_it_shows_up_in_Morocco: Used in desserts and some tagines
Notes_on_variation: Fresh buds should be oily; old ones are dry
Cautions: Clove oil can burn mucous membranes

HERB_033.title: Cardamom
HERB_033.summary: Valued aromatic spice added to coffee and tea for hospitality. Part of spice blends. Imported but thoroughly integrated into Moroccan tradition.

Notes_on_variation: Green and black cardamom are different plants

HERB_034.title: Bay Leaf
HERB_034.summary: Aromatic leaf used in cooking, less prominent in Moroccan tradition than in European. Added to some tagines and stews.

Notes_on_variation: California bay vs true bay laurel

HERB_035.title: Black Pepper
HERB_035.summary: Foundational spice in Moroccan cooking. Present in virtually every savory dish. Considered warming. Freshly ground preferred.

Identification: Black, white, green are same plant
Notes_on_variation: White and green pepper from same plant
Cautions: May irritate in very large amounts

HERB_036.title: Sesame
HERB_036.summary: Seeds used on breads and in pastries. Oil for cooking. Considered nourishing. Both white and black varieties available.

Notes_on_variation: Black sesame more intense than white

HERB_037.title: Olive
HERB_037.summary: Fundamental to Moroccan culture and cuisine. Oil and table olives are dietary staples. Leaf infusion used traditionally for general wellness.

How_it_shows_up_in_Morocco: Ancient groves in Fes, Meknes, Marrakech
Notes_on_variation: Many local olive varieties exist

HERB_038.title: Aloe Vera
HERB_038.summary: Household plant for topical skin care. Gel applied to minor irritations and burns. Common in gardens especially in southern regions.

Notes_on_variation: Different aloe species exist
Cautions: Yellow latex is strong laxative - avoid internal use
May cause skin sensitivity in some

HERB_039.title: Harmel
HERB_039.summary: TOXIC plant used ONLY for ritual fumigation. Never ingest. Seeds burned for protective smoke. Extremely dangerous if misused.

Identification: Bushy plant with finely divided leaves
Preparation_forms: Seeds burned outdoors for smoke only
Notes_on_variation: Distinctive plant, hard to confuse
Cautions: EXTREMELY TOXIC - contains harmine and harmaline

HERB_040.title: Khella
HERB_040.summary: Traditional plant with specific historical uses related to urinary and respiratory comfort. Requires knowledgeable guidance.

Notes_on_variation: May be confused with other Apiaceae

HERB_041.title: Carob
HERB_041.summary: Traditional food and sweetener. Pods eaten as snacks, powder used as chocolate substitute. Molasses as natural sweetener.

Notes_on_variation: Sometimes mixed with chocolate powder

HERB_042.title: Jujube
HERB_042.summary: Traditional fruit considered nourishing and calming. Eaten fresh or dried like dates. Given to children for strength.

Notes_on_variation: Similar to Chinese jujube

HERB_043.title: Date
HERB_043.summary: Central to oasis culture and Moroccan hospitality. Many varieties from different regions. Considered highly nourishing and energizing.

Identification: Range from soft to dry varieties
Notes_on_variation: Many varieties: Medjool, Boufeggous, etc.

HERB_044.title: Fig
HERB_044.summary: Ancient cultivated fruit eaten fresh and dried. Dried figs traditional comfort food. Many varieties from different regions.

Notes_on_variation: Many varieties from green to purple
Cautions: Latex from unripe figs irritates skin

HERB_045.title: Pomegranate
HERB_045.summary: Symbolic fruit in Moroccan culture. Eaten fresh, juiced. Dried peel used traditionally as astringent. Associated with blessings.

Notes_on_variation: Sweet and sour varieties

HERB_046.title: Cassia (Senna)
HERB_046.summary: STRONG LAXATIVE. Known specifically for constipation. Not for regular use. Causes dependency and cramping. Short-term only.

Preparation_forms: Dried leaves or pods in infusion
Notes_on_variation: Different from cinnamon cassia
Cautions: Not for regular use - causes dependency

HERB_047.title: Mastic
HERB_047.summary: Aromatic resin chewed for oral freshness. Used in some pastries. Greek mastic most valued; local shrub produces similar but different resin.

Notes_on_variation: Greek mastic vs local lentisk resin different

HERB_048.title: Smen (Aged Butter)
HERB_048.summary: Traditional preserved aged butter with strong pungent flavor. Given to new mothers and those recovering. Acquired taste central to traditional cuisine.

Identification: Can be aged months to years
Soft or solid depending on temperature
How_it_shows_up_in_Morocco: Made in homes and sold in souks
Notes_on_variation: Fresh butter vs smen very different

HERB_049.title: Honey
HERB_049.summary: Central to Moroccan wellness tradition and hospitality. Many regional varieties. Used for throat comfort and wound care. Quality varies widely.

Notes_on_variation: Eucalyptus, thyme, wild flower, orange blossom types
Cautions: NEVER for infants under 1 year (botulism risk)

HERB_050.title: Artemisia (White Wormwood)
HERB_050.summary: Important steppe plant different from shiba (absinthium). Used for digestive bitters and fumigation. Less potent than its cousin but still requires moderation.

How_it_shows_up_in_Morocco: Wild in High Atlas, Anti-Atlas, southern steppes
Notes_on_variation: Different from Artemisia absinthium (shiba)
Less potent but related uses
